text: 12.6 Semantics of Predicate Logic Prove the following statements of predicate logic (deﬁnition 6.36.). Do not use other results from the lecture notes. a) Let F ′ = ∀ yP ( x, y) . Let F = ∃ xF ′ and G = ∃ xP ( x, f( x) ) . Let A be suitable structure for F , G. Assume A( F ) = 1 . □ b) Let F ′ = ∀ xP ( x) . Then, let F = ¬F ′ and G = ∃ x¬P ( x) . Let A be a suitable structure for both F , G. Then we show that if A is a model for F , it's also a model for G. Assume A( F ) = 1 . □ A( F ) = 1  . ⟺ A( ∃ xF ′) = 1 ( def. F )  . ⟺ A[x→u]( F ′) = 1  for some u in U A ( sem. ∃ )  . ⟺ A[x→u][y→v]( P ( x, y) ) = 1  for some u in U A, for all v in U A ( sem. ∀ )   . ⟹ A[x→u][y→f( u) ]( P ( x, y) ) = 1  for some u in U A ( f( u) = v)  . ⟺ A[y→f( x) ]( ∃ xP ( x, y) ) = 1 ( sem. ∃ )  . ⟺ A( ∃ xP ( x, f( x) ) ) = 1 ( sub. y)  . ⟺ A( G) = 1 ( def. G) A( F ) = 1  . ⟺ A( ¬F ′) = 1 ( def. F )  . ⟺ A( F ′) = 0 ( sem. ¬)  . ⟺ A[x→u]( P ( x) ) = 0  for all u in U A ( sem. ∀ )  . ⟺ A[x→u]( ¬P ( x) ) = 1  for some u in U A ( sem. ¬)   . ⟹ A( ∃ x¬P ( x) ) = 1 ( sem. ∃ )  . ⟺ A( G) = 1 ( def. G)
